Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Culturally Influenced Environmental Narratives

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research improvement project will examine the use of narrative forms to better communicate about the environment among Native American and rural communities in the US. These communities are likely to be among the most vulnerable to the social and ecological impacts of climate variability and environmental change. Understanding how environmental knowledge is perceived and communicated by different groups can lead to the development of stronger, more culturally appropriate, communication tools for at risk populations. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career. The student will contribute to the advancement of geographical science by developing novel methods for better communicating and translating complex science problems to different cultural groups. The findings of this project will have implications for public policy, public health, and sustainability.

The doctoral student will use a mixed methods approach to examine how environmental knowledge is disseminated, perceived, and communicated in distinct ways. Specifically, this research examines (1) how culture shapes environmental perception; and (2) how and whether narrative forms can be used as an effective science communication tool in Native American and traditional rural communities. Through collaborations with local Appalachian and Alaskan cultural and scientific organizations, the doctoral student will collect data through a multi-faceted approach including participant observation at local cultural events, key informant interviews, archival research including historic environmental data and oral history collections, as well as experimental participatory workshops. This research will provide new insights regarding the communication of environmental science to different cultural groups, with implications for improving human health and well-being.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to use cultural narratives as a means of generating new approaches to knowledge production around environmental issues in areas where it is difficult to navigate these issues due to various political, cultural, and social factors. More specifically, this project examined ways that storytelling may be a useful means of creating new approaches to knowledge about climate change in Appalachia and Alaska. Between the beginning and end of this project – and especially in the last several months of 2020 – storytelling has continued to be an important social topic in the U.S. With the move to largely online work, learning, and recreation, one of the key findings from this project – that storytelling creates community – has become especially relevant. However, other key findings from this work regarding storytelling and cultural narratives about the environment have also been key for understanding how residents in Appalachia and Alaska engage with, understand, and act upon their changing environments.

 

Through a combination of qualitative and quantitative research methods, and through the use of more experimental research methods (e.g., collaborative workshops between experts and participants), the PI and Co-PI determined the following: 1) what types of cultural narratives are the most meaningful for engaging with communities about environmental change; 2) how certain ideas and practices about environmental change develops over time in both Appalachia and Alaska; and 3) how these cultural narratives can be utilized to engage communities in deeper conversations about environmental change. As a function of this project, the PI and Co-PI worked with a variety of different communities to answer their research questions, from people whose livelihoods are tied to cultural narratives – storytellers, folklorists, etc. – to experts studying environmental change – U.S. Forest Service scientists, non-profit leaders, etc. This project brought them together in novel ways through publicly attended workshops, which fostered even more community engagement among people in the research sites.

 

To date, this project has resulted in several immediate outcomes. The PI and Co-PI have published articles in The Professional Geographer and Environment & Planning E: Nature and Space, have a book chapter forthcoming in the edited volume, Just Transition in Appalachia (University of Kentucky Press), presented research at conferences, and have worked closely and collaboratively with the organizations involved in their research to continue future research and outreach programs. In particular, this project has resulted in educational opportunities, such as a field research program for schools in Washington D.C. to build relationships with communities in West Virginia through partnerships with an organization named Experience Learning. Further, the Co-PI has been involved in meetings at both the state (WV) and national levels regarding information about energy and climate change with regards to the Green New Deal Resolution proposed in 2019. Finally, the Co-PI maintains contact with many of the participants from this project and is continuing future community-based research that addresses cultural narratives and energy transitions in particular.
